sn24.45:1.2: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:
sn24.45:1.3: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar’?”
sn24.45:1.4: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”
sn24.45:2.1: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:
sn24.45:2.2: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’
sn24.45:2.6: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:
sn24.45:2.7: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’
sn24.45:3.4: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
sn24.45:3.5: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar’?”
sn24.45:3.8: When this exists, grasping at this, the view arises:
sn24.45:3.9: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’
sn24.45:3.19: When this exists, grasping at this, the view arises:
sn24.45:3.20: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’”
